text: one of the things that graphic designers
are trained to do um I think is to part
of their training is to think very
carefully about what's called the
difference between figure and ground so
in an image there's figure the bits that
stand out if you like and ground that's
typically seen as the background and
there's all sorts of principles um for
creating figure and ground that come
from an area of psychology called gal
psychology so I've just drawn a pattern
there and if I asked you what that
pattern I don't know how you'll describe
it but I predict that many people would
say it's two squares Follow by two
squares followed by two circles Follow
by two squares they probably wouldn't
say it's a square followed by two
squares with a gap in between followed
by a square and a circle with a gap in
between or whatever and that's because
the way that we process images is we use
a a calic principle called um uh
grouping uh to essentially group these
together so we tend to emphasize these
two as being belonging to each other
there are other that we won't go through
the whole thing if I asked you what's
that most people would tend to say
that's a circle because we have a
principle called closure where we look
for closure in images we close them up
what's interesting is the camera in our
aesthetic codes app it doesn't operate
on these principles it doesn't see that
as a circle but a human does and that's
the principles that clever designers
start to exploit so they recognize they
can put extra lines and extra bits here
that are nothing to do with the code
that lead your eye to see these and they
can hide the code within other bits of
the image so in this for instance let's
have a look at what some of the code
might be so yeah in this example there
are bits that I think are the code here
um there are bits that look a bit like
the code but they're not um because
these leaves don't join up so that to me
anyway looks quite similar to that but
to the computer it's completely
different and that's that gastal
principle of closure that's going on and
there're kind of various others so this
is one of the I think really nice things
about this is that graphic designers
once once they understand how the system
works they're
exploiting the fact that human
perception of an image is different from
our apps perception of that image and
that those things only partially overlap
and once you understand that you can get
really creative and funky about the
patterns you make and that relies on
this almost kind of you know
psychological understanding of of of
what's going on and also in a way I
suppose you can make any pattern and
then just make a few changes to make it
fit the yes yeah yeah great example is
once you know the rules we can go back
to my original not very beautiful design
and we can now make it Beautiful by
adding a few lovely extra embellishments
around it that actually make no
difference to the image at all I can
extend this out and make it appear
highly significant to your eye but to
our camera that's made no difference and
that's what the designers are doing here
they've got embellishments they've even
worked out that the some of the colors
because our app maps the image to black
and white that some of these colors here
will map to White white and some to
Black so essentially they're visible to
your eye but invisible to the camera
again so they even figured out
eventually how to exploit color I think
that's a really nice General point that
as all sorts of computer vision
techniques become more common place in
the world even things like the connect
that we're using to interact within
games that computers and people perceive
the world in different ways and that
those differences are sometimes the
source of creativity and those are the
things you can actually kind of if you
like exploit to make really interesting
experiences
